alert.note: Alert for Kauai North; Kauai Southwest; Maui Central Valley North; Maui Windward West; Molokai North; Molokai West; Molokai Windward; Niihau; Oahu North Shore; Waianae Coast; Windward Haleakala (Hawaii) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: High Surf Warning issued January 22 at 3:54AM HST until January 23 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu
info.description: ...HIGH SURF WARNING FOR NORTH AND WEST FACING SHORES OF NIIHAU KAUAI OAHU AND MOLOKAI...NORTH FACING SHORES OF MAUI...AND WEST FACING SHORES OF THE BIG ISLAND... .Observations at the offshore and nearshore buoys have surged well above predicted levels early this morning, which supports larger surf and an increasing likelihood for coastal impacts today. Surf at this level coinciding with the early morning high tide cycle around daybreak will translate to erosion issues with water sweeping across portions of the beach that typically remain dry. Minor overwash onto the typical vulnerable coastal roads will be possible early this morning, especially when the larger, more infrequent, sets roll through. ...HIGH SURF WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM HST SUNDAY... * WHAT...Surf of 35 to 50 feet along north facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui. Surf of 25 to 35 feet along west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, and Molokai. * WHERE...North and west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, and Molokai, and north facing shores of Maui. * WHEN...Surf will peak today, then lower to advisory levels Sunday. * IMPACTS...Very High. Expect ocean water surging and sweeping across beaches, coastal benches, and lava flows creating the potential for impacts to coastal properties and infrastructure, including roadways. Powerful longshore and rip currents will be present at most beaches. Large breaking waves and strong currents may impact harbor entrances and channels causing challenging boat handling. Strong currents in exposed harbors, such as Haleiwa, could become strong.
info.instruction: Large, breaking surf, significant shorebreak, and dangerous currents make entering the water very hazardous. Anyone entering the water could face significant injury or death.
